Key Arguments: The legislation will lead to self-censorship by digital platforms, limiting freedom of speech.
The bill's definitions of misinformation and disinformation are vague and could lead to over-correction by platforms.
The exclusion of government and certain media from the bill's provisions creates an uneven playing field and implies a bias towards these sources.
The serious harm threshold is poorly defined and could lead to pre-emptive exclusion of content.
The bill could marginalize dissenting opinions and fuel narratives of suppression.
Notable Quotes: The Libertarian Party opposes and condemns this Bill in the strongest possible terms.
In practice, the self-censorship that is likely to occur in this stage will tend to take a more restrictive approach than the definitions provided in the Bill.
Western civilization has a long and proud tradition of scientific method characterized by exposing hypotheses and theories to debate, scrutiny, and criticism.
The exclusion of certain bodies from the misinformation and disinformation provisions places a further arbitrary value judgement on the accuracy and truthfulness of content from these sources.

The AEC is a political body, that is not immune from making mistakes, behaving in a way that violates community expectations of it, or receiving justified criticism when it falls short of these standards.
